dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men, CAESAR and MARTY "DUCKS," stand at  the   end of deserted bar, talking quietly, oblivious to  the   exotic grinding her pelvis on a pole in the middle  of   the sma stage. Body language and charisma tell us   that   Caesar boss, "Ducks" his lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Peezee. Gotta be.    He hates your fuckin' guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brooding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else knew about the money? And how did Peezee know they popped Tony Cisco when we didn't even hear about it 'til last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs heavily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is so hard to understand here? You said yourself Peezee was a mamaluke and you couldn't trust him. Now suddenly you're soft on the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't think it was him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll bite. If not Peezee, then who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly rising to his full height)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was you, Ducks. Caesar starts to walk away as the bartender, now holding sawed-off shotgun, moves closer to Ducks. The exotic danc splits in a hurry through a curtain at the back of the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kiddin'! Caesar stops at the door where two of his soldiers have

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: appeared, holding AUTOMATIC WEAPONS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caesar, you know me! What kind of fuckin' idiot would I have to be to try that shit with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dead fuckin' idiot. As he walks out the door, the soldiers OPEN FIRE on Marty "Ducks." Caesar doesn't look back.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: The title credits come up on the made-for-cable series we been watching, "Little Caesar." CLAPPING AND CHEERING fro O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximum-security prisoners are gathered around watching t favorite show in the rec room. In the front row is PAUL V former New York crime boss, and a couple of other wiseguy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garbage.   Change the channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Paul. The WISEGUY gets up and starts switching channels on the A couple of CONVICTS in the back start to protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   What're you doin', asshole! Vitti turns and stares at them.      They fall silent immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Vitti. Didn't mean any disrespect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punks. Vitti turns the page and sees a huge headline in the Post MOB SHRINK TELLS ALL. He gets up, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to bed. Vitti stands up and heads back to his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Vitti approaches his cell, he sees a prison guard stan by. His cellmate, EARL, a giant of a man, comes out of th cell carrying his bedroll and a box containing his other meager possessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's goin' on, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're transferring me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know. Thanks for looking out for me, Mr. Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     Take it easy. He notices something in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Earl.     Is that my after-shave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blanches)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I just grabbed stuff -- I didn't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.     Keep it.   Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.     See you around. Earl exits with the guard. Vitti hesitates a moment, then warily steps into his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cellblock is quiet. A guard stops outside the darkene cell, looks around to make sure no one is watching, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pulls out a GUN with a SILENCER, reaches through the bars FIRES REPEATEDLY into Vitti's shadowy form under the blan Then he slips away as quietly as he appeared. ON his exit we PAN DOWN TO Vitti, unhurt, curled up under bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deluxe casket flanked by elaborate floral displays and easel displaying a portrait of the deceased, Dr. Isaac So Mourners fill the pews, standees at the back, an overflow crowd. BEN SOBEL sits in the front row, staring at the casket with his wife, LAURA, his son, MICHAEL, now a teenager, BEN'S MOTHER, and her friend, DR. JOYCE BROTHER At the podium, the RABBI is speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now I'd like to call on Isaac's son, Dr. Ben Sobel, who would like to say a few words. Ben rises and crosses solemnly to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing audience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very difficult for me to talk about my father, because in a sense I'm talking about two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, of    course, is the public Isaac Sobel,    the eminent psychotherapist and popular    author known to millions of readers    around the world. Laura, Michael and Ben's Mother listen proudly to the eul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second Isaac Sobel is the private man -- my father -- Dad. And for those of you who knew him well and knew our family -- well, let's face it -- my father was a psychotic, mind- fucking prick. An arrogant, abusive, ego-inflated -- A RINGING CELL PHONE interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: still seated in the front row, daydreaming. The RINGING CONTINUES as all the mourners and even the Rabbi discreet check their cell phones. Then Ben realizes it's his, fumbles for the phone in his jacket pocket and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? The mourners mutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess who, you fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben turns away from Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? (to Laura)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to, uh, take this. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a good time. Vitti is disheveled, his hair messed, his shirt buttoned wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a good time? Let me explain something to you. I'm in fucking Hell right now. This is not a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk right now.     My father died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what does that have to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me later --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hang up on, Sobel!    They're tryin' to kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: He stands there for a long beat just staring, the DIAL TO BUZZING in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti and another WISEGUY pass through the cafeteria line with their trays. Vitti now looks catatonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, they got tapioca. I love tapioca. (looks at Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Paul? Vitti just stares, wild-eyed, actually drooling a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have your tapioca? A guard, the one who tried to kill him, watches Vitti fro his post. Then he nods to someone across the room. COYOTE, a heavily-muscled and tattooed gang member, nods response. Vitti walks past the table where Coyote is sitting with o tough Hispanic gang members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Fredo! Or is it Guido? His friends laugh. Vitti stops and stares dumbly at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep walkin', Don Corleone. There is a tense moment, then Vitti bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Vitti laughs harder, strangely manic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, shut up, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Vitti can't stop. He drops his tray of slop, splatter food on the men. Coyote leaps to his feet and pulls a shi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dead man, jefe! Coyote lunges at Vitti with the knife, but Vitti suddenly whirls around, bashes Coyote in the face with his food tr and bursts into song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing, with appropriate dance moves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'When you're a Jet, You're a Jet all the way, From your first cigarette To your last dyin' day...' Prisoners and guards stare at him like he's nuts. Coyote stabs at him again, but Vitti dodges and smashes h over the head with the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'When you're a Jet, If the shit hits the fan, You got brothers around, You're a family man...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dead man, jefe! Coyote rushes him, but Vitti sidesteps and hits him in th face. Guards move in from all sides.   Vitti jumps up on the tabletop to escape them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kicking at them, singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I like to be in America, Okay by me in America...' The guards drag him down and cuff his hands behind him, t carry him out stiff as a board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tonight, tonight, won't be just any night -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limo pulls up to an old, but well-maintained suburban house, the family gets out and starts walking to the hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family crosses to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs deeply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe what you said about him. Cold and withholding? You had to tell everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. Why didn't you just take a swing at the casket? Ben opens the front door and they go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family enters the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I might have strayed from my notes a little. I'm dealing with a lot of stuff here. Grief is a process. Laura notices FBI AGENTS CERRONE and MILLER waiting for t in the living room. Cerrone is an attractive woman in her late twenties, wearing a dangerously-short skirt. Miller a clean-cut man in his thirties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Sobel, I'm Agent Miller, this is Special Agent Cerrone, Federal Bureau of Investigation. We'd just like to ask you a few questions, if we could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask what this is about?    We just came from the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know this is a difficult time for you, Dr. Sobel. Sorry about your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, I'm going to miss him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: terribly. Ben gestures for them to sit. Laura and Michael both look at him doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- there were issues -- as, I think, there are with any father and son. He wasn't especially warm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben -- once today? Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm just saying, in spite of all that -- Agent Cerrone crosses her legs, a move that does not go unnoticed by Ben and Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he was a great, great legs. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Sobel, you received a call this morning from Paul Vitti? Laura shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think Paul Vitti called me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we monitor and record all his phone calls from Sing Sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then yes.   He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was him on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you didn't tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.   Talk about withholding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told her -- (nodding at Agent Cerrone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told her at the drop of a hat. Agents Cerrone and Miller eye each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's with the F.B.I.   She needs to know these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. And I don't. Why tell Laura? She couldn't possibly handle a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks need a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't need me anymore, I'll be in the kitchen. (to Agent Cerrone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And two words of advice -- from one professional woman to another -- Pant. Suit. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's grieving. It's a process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We understand. (prompting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Paul Vitti and I were involved in some organized crime activity a couple of years ago. I mean, I wasn't involved -- not 'involved' involved -- I was just trying to help him therapeutically, and some people tried to, uh, kill us. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shortly after you spoke, he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seemed to have some kind of breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of breakdown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better go up there and see for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti huddles in the corner of a bare, white, padded cell rocking, completely out of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I feel pretty, oh, so pretty, I feel pretty and witty and bright...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben watches through a two-way mirror with the prison psychiatrist, DR. CUTLER. They can hear Vitti through a wall-mounted speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm treating him with Thioridazine, 300 milligrams, T.I.D. That seems to keep him pretty calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would keep a parade pretty calm. He just keeps singing West Side Story songs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tonight,' 'Maria,' the balcony scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balcony scene?   Both parts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Get him to do 'Officer Krupke.' It's really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Dr. Cutler enter.   Vitti doesn't seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Who's the pretty girl in the mirror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: there? What mirror? Where?       Who can that attractive girl be?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, it's me.    Ben Sobel.   Paul? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a look to Dr. Cutler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy. (to Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on, Maria?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rumble -- it's tonight! I have to get out of here. I don't want to die. No, Chino, no! Vitti's jaw suddenly goes slack and he slumps in his seat staring forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?   Paul? Ben waves a hand in front of Vitti's face.       Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how it's been. He sings for a while, then he goes completely catatonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Can we take him to an examining room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti sits inert on the examination table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already did a neurological work- up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. No tumors, no aneurisms, no sign of stroke --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben slaps Vitti's face lightly a couple times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely catatonic -- He pulls on Vitti's ears and nose.     Vitti does not rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally gone. Well, I don't think he's smart enough to be faking. Street smart, yes, but we're talking about an I.Q. just north of a bedroom slipper. Ben checks Vitti out of the corner of his eye. No reactio Then Ben takes a sharp needle from an instrument tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if I just stuck him with this needle, he probably wouldn't even respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    Try it. Ben hesitates for a moment to see if Vitti will crack, th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- He sticks the needle into Vitti's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursts into song)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Boy, boy, crazy boy, keep cool, boy! Got a rocket in your pocket, keep cool-y cool boy -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti is sitting at a table facing Ben.     Dr. Cutler ob from a chair in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, we're going to    give you some tests to assess your    mental condition. There's no pressure    -- just answer as best you can. Do I     have your consent to share the results    of these tests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy's mad at me because I made a boom on the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that as a yes. Okay, I'm going to show you ten cards, each containing a picture of an inkblot. I want you to look at each card and tell me what you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you.   I see him.   I see a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Focus, Paul. You haven't seen the card yet. (hands him first card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this look like to you? Take your time. Vitti looks at the wrong side of the card.    It's all wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Paul, the other side. Vitti turns it over and makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bat.   A big bat. Or a weasel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking notes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bat or weasel. All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's got a little girl -- no, it's a little boy -- in his teeth -- and he's shakin' him and shakin' him 'cause the kid didn't wipe himself good -- and the kid is screaming because the bat-weasel ripped out his throat and the blood is shootin' out of his neck vein. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the blood. Doctor Cutler looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the pussy with the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making more notes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pussy with teeth. Next card.

dialogues.speaker: SHAPES TEST
dialogues.text: Vitti is literally trying to pound a square peg into a ro hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now try repeating the numbers backwards. For instance, if I was 1- 2-3, you will say 3-2-1. Okay, 7-3-8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again.   7-3-8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue.

dialogues.speaker: THEMATIC APPERCEPTION TEST
dialogues.text: Vitti studies a vague and ambiguous photograph of a man standing beside a bed with a sleeping woman and child on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me what you think is going on in this picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a picture of a guy -- nice, hardworking guy -- comes home and finds out his wife's been screwin' this midget while he was out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled, makes a note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screwing a midget. And how does the story end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he works over the midget for a while, then he blows 'em away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife or the midget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smirks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick question, right?    Both of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Paul. Last test. In this one, I'm going to start a sentence and you complete it any way you want to. Ready? 'I get angry -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're supposed to complete the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.   I said 'yes.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't asking if you agreed or disagreed; it was more like, 'I get angry when -- '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- whenever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that about does it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben meets with RICHARD CHAPIN, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based on his symptoms and the test results, I'd say brief psychotic disorder -- if it persists, possibly schizophreniform disorder. And Dr. Cutler agrees with my diagnosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he's crazy?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Dr. Cutler?   No, he's annoying, but --

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Not crazy. At least not permanently. In certain people, continuous exposure to an extremely stressful situation -- soldiers in combat, for instance, disaster victims, a hostage situation, or being locked up in a maximum security prison with someone trying to kill you -- it can produce a temporary psychotic state.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: How temporary?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: A day, a week, up to a month -- if the precipitating stressors are removed.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: (musing) Which means he's not going to get any better while he's still in the can.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He could get worse. He could deteriorate to the point where he'd be permanently schizophrenic.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: Then I'd say he's got a real problem, because he goes before the parole board in four weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You think they'll let him out?

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I'm sure they'll want to release a major Mafia figure who's now totally deranged on top of it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (thinks) Well, couldn't you release him to    a halfway house or some place where    he could get some decent treatment? Based on my earlier work with him,    I don't think he's dangerous, and I think he was making a real effort    to reform himself.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: You do, huh? (thinks for a long moment) Okay. Then I'll tell you what. I'm gonna release him into your custody.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Mine? Me? No, this is a bad time for me. My father just died -- and I've got this bulging disc in my neck -- and we're redecorating, which is a total nightmare. I can't --

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: You want to see him killed in prison?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: Or sent to a facility for the criminally insane.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: Then he's all yours. I'm going to talk to the Bureau of Prisons and get you certified as a temporary federal institution.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (stricken) What?    I can't be an institution.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPIN
dialogues.text: (firm) You've got thirty days to get him in shape for his parole hearing. That means sane, sober and gainfully employed. But let me warn you, Doctor. If he fucks up in any way -- if he flees, or if I find out that this whole thing was just a setup so he could get back on the street and return to a life of crime -- I will hold you totally responsible, and I'll see that you are stripped of your license and prosecuted to the full extent of the law. Are we clear?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (gulp) Yes.    We're clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still want him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat to decide)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gate opens and Ben coaxes Vitti outside.     A guard them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Paul -- this way. Vitti comes out carrying an overnight bag, walking like a zombie. Ben leads him over to the car and opens the door him. Vitti keeps walking, passing the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Paul. Over here.      Here we go. Ben helps Vitti into the car.     One of Vitti's legs is outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leg, Paul.   Leg up. Ben lifts Vitti's leg into the car and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben STARTS the CAR and pulls away with Vitti still slumpe his seat. Once out of sight of the prison, Vitti straight and turns on Ben, suddenly lucid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking son-of-a-bitch! Where the fuck do you get off sticking me with a needle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it! I knew you were faking! You used me to get you out of prison!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Took you long enough. I was singin' West Side Story for three fuckin' days. I'm half a fag already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call you to say somebody's trying to kill me and you hang up on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at the funeral home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my fuckin' doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me me me me!   He's dead!   Get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hearing yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perfunctorily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm deeply sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see how touched you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference?   You hated him anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved my father. I'm feeling a lot of grief right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sensing it, but if you say so. Ben nervously pops a pill and swallows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:   pill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decongestant. I'm getting over a cold. All right, what's going on? Who's after you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- take your pick. Could be my old family, or could be the Rigazzis. Ever heard of Lou Rigazzi - - Lou 'The Wrench'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why "The Wrench"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he twisted a guy's head off once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off. Fuckin' Calabrese -- animals. And comin' from me you know that's a big compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they'd be flattered.    So --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The feds are really putting the pressure on. The families are fighting each other again -- what's left of 'em. It's the fall of the fuckin' Roman Empire. It's World War Three out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what does that have to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They knew I was gettin' out soon and the last thing anybody wants to see is me getting into it on either side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you just explain to them -- that you're out of it now, that you're starting a new life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah,   they'll probably want to throw me a   party and give me a gold watch. Trust   me -- nobody's lookin' forward to me   being out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, yeah, my future looks real fuckin' rosy. Ben can't believe what he's gotten himself into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Vitti pull into the driveway and get out of the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to grab your stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna be here that long. Jelly's pickin' me up in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul! I don't think you understand. You're in my custody. I could get in a lot of trouble if you screw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.     I'll call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You want to go back to Sing Sing? Thursday's meatloaf night. I can have you back there in no time. The U.S. Attorney was very clear. You stay with me; therapy every day; you can't leave the area without permission --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, my father now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you    have to get a job as soon as you're    well enough, which is now. So are you    coming in with me or do I have to make    a phone call? Vitti relents and grabs his stuff from the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm comin'.    Some fuckin' life this is gonna be. He follows Ben up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapin is conferring with another U.S. ATTORNEY, DAVIS, a Agents Miller and Cerrone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think Vitti is crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's about as crazy as I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it. Locked up, he was absolutely no use to me. But back on the street, Vitti's still powerful enough to pose a threat to both families. It's like throwing gasoline on a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can use Vitti to escalate this war, we might just end up putting them all away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's if he goes back to his old life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If? People like Paul Vitti     don't change. This guy's been a     menace to society since he was twelve    years old. Being a criminal is all he    knows. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna head straight for trouble. Then all we have to do is sit back and pick up the pieces. We could get twenty, maybe even thirty indictments next time the grand jury convenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Giuliani started this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You running for mayor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could happen.     Just stick with Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Laura are in the kitchen, cleaning up the dinner dishes. Ben is wearing an apron that says "To Heck with Housework!" and a pair of Playtex rubber gloves. Laura is angrily muscling dishes around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you? How could you bring him here? That -- (shuddering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- mobster -- in my home -- eating off my dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the plate in her hand, disgusted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewww. She scrubs the plate with manic energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have a lot of choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there's a law that says you have to bring a gangster home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. He's in my custody.      I'm a federal institution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be in an institution.     Why couldn't he just go home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife and kids aren't here. They're in Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohio! Sure. Everyone gets to be in Ohio except me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His life was threatened and he didn't want to endanger his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How thoughtful! What about endangering our family? (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think my teeth are loose.     Feel my teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, your teeth are fine. I know it's an imposition, but what could I do? I didn't want him here. They -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't want him, I didn't want him, but here he is! She looks up and jumps when she sees Vitti standing there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering, cheerful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody said something about coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was you.    You said you wanted some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the holdup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you make your friend some coffee. I'm going upstairs to take a long bath and hopefully drown. Laura smiles at the two men, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to forgive her.     She's usually a great hostess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. She's uncomfortable. The whole situation's a little awkward with me bein' here -- but let's face it, Emily fuckin' Post she's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily fuckin' Post. Well, that explains why she rarely used her middle name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I got a friend coming over.     I didn't want you to be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What    kind of friend? Because if it's 'The    Wrench,' or 'The Power Drill' or any    other kind of tool    --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that kind of friend.     It's a personal thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't stay late, will they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stares at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you really that pussy-whipped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not -- this has nothing to do with Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard her busting your balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were having a disagreement. A certain amount of conflict is normal in a marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you're pussy-whipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Whippy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, this is only temporary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? I didn't hear you the tenth fuckin' time. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben knocks on Michael's door and walks in without waiting be asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is sitting up in bed reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, can we talk for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.     What?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I know the last few weeks have been kind of tough with Grandpa -- dying and everything -- and it might've felt to you like I didn't have time for you or I didn't care about how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, it didn't.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Good. Because I want you to know that you can talk to me about stuff and that I can really listen and understand what you're going through.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I do, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And if I seemed a little hard on Grandpa, it's just that your grandfather was a hard man in a lot of ways. He wanted everything done his way and sometimes I just felt like nothing I ever did was good enough. I don't want it to be that way with us.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It's not.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And you know, at times like this we all might start questioning our own mortality and you might be thinking how devastated you'd be if I died. Right?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No.   Not really.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That's good. Good talk. And I realize it's all a little hectic right now, but this Paul Vitti thing is only temporary, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, really? I didn't hear you the tenth fuckin' time.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That's not funny.   Good night, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Whippy. Ben exits, shaking his head. The moment he's gone, the rumpled blankets next to Michae shift, and a CUTE, PUNKY 16-YEAR-OLD GIRL emerges from hi under the comforter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get home. What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Parenting stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suburban street is dark and quiet and all the lights off in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhhh!   Ohhhhh, Paul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. We PAN UP the foot of Ben and Laura's b and find them both wide awake staring straight up at the ceiling, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh, God!   Oh, oh, oh, oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has to be some kind of record, don't you think? It's been like forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long are you going to let them go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them? How much longer can he go? Another twenty minutes, I'm either breaking it up or calling the Guinness Book of Records. The MOANING shifts into low gear, more guttural and besti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, give me a break.    She's got to be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: faking.   Nobody sounds like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suggestively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not entirely true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sometimes you do sound like that. The O.S. MOANING kicks up another notch. Laura rolls over and jams her pillow over her ears. Ben growls, exasperate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael's girlfriend is gone. He has his bedroom door ope crack and he's standing there holding a small tape record and smiling broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high-pitched now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, ah, ah, ah...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agents Cerrone and Miller sit in a sedan with a small, sophisticated-looking microphone trained on the Sobel hou just down the street. They hear the high-pitched MOANING. Miller gives Cerrone a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.    Nobody sounds like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben takes a deep breath and knocks sharply on the guest r door. The heavy MOANING STOPS. After a moment, Vitti appears wearing only a bathrobe. Ben can see the beautifu SHEILA sitting naked on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a 17-year-old son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let him get his own fuckin' girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm right in the middle of someone. Sheila starts to light a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss? Excuse me.     There's no smoking in this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael freezes, about to light a cigarette himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben comes down the stairs with Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minding my own fuckin' business, like you should be doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a little hard with the live sex show going on in the guest room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been in prison for two and a half years. What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted to do, but you told me I had no choice -- it was either here or Sing Sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to punish you. These aren't my rules, but I have a responsibility here. Besides, I thought you might like a nice home- cooked meal after being in prison that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I've been jerkin' off about for eight hundred consecutive nights -- a nice home- cooked meal. (making a jerking motion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh, tuna casserole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That girl is not staying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I'm really jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear nothin' comin' out of your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't think it's necessary to wake the neighbors every time we have sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if you're really quiet, you might be able to do it without even wakin' up your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moaning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh.   Ohhh. Ben looks curiously at Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her if I wasn't back in two minutes to start without me. I gotta go. Vitti heads back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a good start, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Ben are hosting a brunch for the out-of-town relatives. Laura offers a basket of bagels to a seated, older woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Ester, I'm so sorry we had to put you up at the hotel. We wanted you here with us, but we had an unexpected house guest. She glares at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father always had room for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (mutters to Laura)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I lose a parent, I'll be sure to reserve the guest room. A DOOR SLAMS somewhere, then Sheila storms into the room sobbing, her hair askew, tucking her blouse into her skir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Paul! You just go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead! Get out of here, you crazy fuckin' whore. Vitti charges into the room, his robe open. From the reactions of everyone in the room, it's clear he's not wearing anything under it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to turning tricks in Jersey for all I fuckin' care. Sheila exits and slams the front door.   Vitti sees every staring at him. He closes his robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin'? (sees buffet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we got food. Good. Vitti heads for the buffet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti bellies up to the buffet, stepping between an older couple. He eyes the food disdainfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great. Jew food. Who do you have to fuck to get some bacon around here? The woman reacts in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you, I'm guessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snags Vitti's arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we go to my office?   I'll make you a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Vitti enter.   Vitti still in his robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it with your relatives?   They tend to overreact quite a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. All you did was flash everybody in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? From the look of 'em, some of those broads haven't seen the old salcicc' in a long time. It's good for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when the paramedics revive my Aunt Goldie, I'll be sure to ask her. Sit. Vitti starts for Ben's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah ah ah! He points Vitti to the sofa and takes his own chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First I'm gonna find out who's tryin' to kill me. I'm a target. Somebody could shoot right through that window -- blow my fuckin' head off. Ben sees that he's in the line of fire, gets up and moves of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's a priority. Have you thought about what you're going to do for work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm too big for a jockey so I was thinkin' maybe a hairdresser. They'll call me Mr. Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. There must be something you like to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like hitting a guy on the head with a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sporting goods. We'll check the want ads tomorrow but don't get your hopes up. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shylocking, bookmaking, unions, the usual --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I? I'm the guy who's paying you $150 an hour to play these stupid fuckin' games. You know who I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.   I mean what are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, 'What am I?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to know how you see yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me very fuckin' nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just answer the question.     What are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? The boss of what -- Jelly? You're not the boss of me. So what are you the boss of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, you're good. I see what you're doing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pissing me off is what you're doing. Look at me. It's starting again, the anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've    spent your whole life becoming who you    are and now you can't be that anymore    -- that's gotta be scary. If you're    not Paul Vitti the mob boss, who are    you? Vitti is at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's think. When you were a kid, What did you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    Who remembers that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must've wanted to be something when you were little -- fireman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball player?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Astronaut?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Al Capone?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe.    What did you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We're not talking about me.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Fine.   I wanted to be a philatelist.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: You wanted to look up people's assholes all day?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, Paul, I believe you're thinking of a proctologist. I wanted to collect rare and unusual stamps.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: You must've been a lot of laughs when you were a kid. Lonely, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Big time.      So what did you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: It's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You afraid to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Then tell me.    I'm not here to judge you.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: (a beat) Okay. When I was really little -- like seven or eight -- maybe I wanted to be a cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: A cowboy.   Really?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: Yeah. My father gave   me a cowboy suit -- you know, the  vest, the chaps, the cap guns --  the whole thing. And he used to   take me up to my uncle's farm in  New Jersey and lead me around on  this pony. Yippee-i-o. You happy   now?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So you watched cowboy movies and TV shows with your father.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: Everybody. The whole family.     My father loved 'Gunsmoke.'

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sheriff Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: (corrects him) Marshal Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Marshal.    So who were your favorite cowboys?

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: This is so fuckin' retarded.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Paul!

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: All right. Gene Autry, Roy Rogers, the Lone Ranger --

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Interesting.   They're all good guys.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, that's important. You didn't want to be the bad guy. You wanted to be the hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    Nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why didn't you become a cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lived in East Harlem! I joined a street gang when I was 12 and that was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something else happened when you were twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something that made you very sad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dodgers moved from Brooklyn to L.A. Everybody took it pretty hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We playin' a guessing game here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul! Your father was murdered! Right in front of you. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I remember? I think about it every fuckin' day of my life. What's that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got everything   to do with it. He gave you the cowboy   suit. With a white hat. He was    in the mob, but he wanted you to be a   good guy, didn't he? Vitti starts thinking about his father and starts to weep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't want you in the gang life. He only did it himself so you wouldn't have to. He was trying to buy you a better life than his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying harder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always said he wanted me to go to college. I didn't even finish high school. He really starts sobbing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Paul, this could be a  great opportunity for you. You're   right back where you were when you  were twelve. You've got some big   choices to make. Vitti fights to regain control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Okay.   That's enough of that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not shit, Paul. My point is, when you're a child, you think anything is possible. Wouldn't it be great to think like that now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (retreating back into his cynicism)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just sprinkle some fuckin' fairy dust on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying you've got to keep an open mind and explore some new possibilities. Try some different things -- maybe you'll connect with one of them. There's a career counselor I work with. I can call him for you. He may be able to help you find a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean working for somebody? I'm supposed to take orders from some guy who used to get me coffee? (starts sweating and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: breathing hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that. It's not right. It's not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know unless you try? Suddenly one of the WINDOWS behind Vitti SHATTERS. Ben dives for cover. Silence -- then another RAP on the window. Ben looks out and sees JELLY in the back yard, tossing stones at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Doc. Sorry about the window. Ben waves him around to the side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jelly is loading up a plate of food from the buffet, talk to the elderly relatives. Laura stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love  lox and bagels. I dated a Jewish  woman once. Actually, she might  have been the love of my life, but my  mother broke it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was always hockin' me a chinick about the madels. A wonderful woman, my mother, but she fuckin' hates the Hebes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. (noting mountain of food on his plate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More smoked salmon? Don't be shy. Ben enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jelly -- what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makin' new friends. How's it going, Doc? I brought some clothes for Mr. Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Jelly. I'd love to catch up with you -- outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it. (to Laura)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mrs. S. (to others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, everybody.    Ess gesunterhait. Jelly and Ben exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Jelly walk out to the driveway where Jelly's Buic parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Long time no see.     You look good, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be pleasant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, Jelly -- you look -- (can't find words for how he looks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a haircut? I thought you were in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would appear not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New trial. The evidence in my first trail was, you know, tainted. Turns out two of the witnesses against me changed their minds -- and the third one, he died after a short illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunshot wound to the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not an illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it is short. Vitti, now dressed, comes out of the house and crosses to car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got stuff to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he gets into the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down. I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave without my permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?   Watch me.   Drive, Jelly. Jelly STARTS the CAR and slowly backs out of the driveway Ben runs after the car, talking to Vitti through the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, Paul. I forbid you to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop sweating, Doc.     I'll be back. Vitti puts the window up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you screw this up, Paul -- Paul! The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!   Shit, shit, shit! Ben turns and sees his Aunt Goldie on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the fat one -- he's single?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers lounge at the bar, keeping a respectful distance from the capos seated at a table in the rear. All eyes tu as the door opens and Vitti enters. SAL MASIELLO, Vitti's old consigliere rises and warmly bu warily welcomes Vitti back into the fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paulie, great to see you! You're lookin' good, kid. Lookin' very good. Jelly, how are ya? Vitti embraces him and they sit down with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Paul, we heard you had some trouble while you were away. Some 'mental' problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm okay. It was an act. I had to pretend I was nuts. There were people watching me all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors. They never woulda let me out if they thought I was normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you ain't crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see crazy? Just tell me who's trying to kill me. I'll show you crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a war, Paul -- nobody's safe right now. The Rigazzis are walkin' all over us. We got next to nothing coming in, and I don't have to tell you, you don't buy a lot of muscle without money these days. We need you, Paul. The family needs you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it, Sal.   I'm out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Paulie. Nobody used to do the big jobs like you. Air France-- they're still talkin' about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal, even if I wanted to -- the feds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After your father died, I always treated you like my own son. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a good man. I still miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll think about it.    For me, Paulie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what is this -- a fuckin' funeral here? You just got back from college for Chrissakes. We should be havin' a party for you. (to bartender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Nino, give everybody a round here. We gotta drink to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Sal.    I gotta go talk to the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. No problem. It's good to have you back, Paul. (embraces him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget what I said. We're countin' on you. Vitti gives his old friend a pat on the back and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jelly pulls up, Vitti gets out and strides up to the fron door of a nice home on Staten Island and RINGS the BELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is opened by EDDIE DEVOL, early thirties, dark a sullen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Yeah, what?'    That's how you answer the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Vitti punches Eddie in the mouth, sending him sprawling b into the living room. Several other bodyguards are watchi television, caught off guard by Vitti's sudden entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti enters. PATTY LOPRESTI, mid-forties, still sexy eve in an apron, is mixing cake batter in a bowl with an elec mixer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul -- what a nice surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin', Patty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.   It's good. Give me a kiss, you. Patty hugs and kisses him, taking the opportunity to pat down for a weapon or a hidden wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear about Carmine.     He was a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You live with a person twenty- one years, then one day they're

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pulling his torso out of the river. It's hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet -- especially with all the talk about you being the one who put him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I try not to gossip, Paul. It's ugly. Just a sec. (screaming to ceiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle! Teresa! It's ten-thirty! Stop fucking around and get ready for ballet! (to Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard being a single parent and a career woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure you're very busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pressure -- it's awful. For instance, a lot of people think, now that you're out, you're going to try and take the family back from me. But I said, no, Paul would never do that. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, how are Marie and the kids? Still in Ohio? In Shaker Heights? At 1356 Locust? Vitti explodes, reaches across the counter and grabs her the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You even go near them, you crazy bitch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me call my guys in. You may need the shit kicked out of you, but not in here. I just mopped. Vitti lets her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothing clothes, flushed and a little excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.   Have you been working out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I been workin' out who's trying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to kill me. I'd love to hear your thoughts on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dog-eat-dog world out there. Nobody's gonna be safe unless we can end this thing with the Rigazzis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then you didn't have nothin' to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Paul. You actually think I would kill you? All the years we've known each other -- the Christmas parties, the fun times at the beach. It wouldn't be right. I want us to be friends. (smiles demurely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows? Maybe we'll be more than friends. Want to lick my beaters? She holds the beaters out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (declining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I gotta see a guy about a business thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of business? You know, if you get something going, we would expect some kind of consideration -- a little taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is a legitimate business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shudders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Paul. I just got a chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to be left alone.   Put my life back together -- straight  up this time. Put the word out, will   ya? Nobody's got nothin' to worry  about from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Paul.    I understand. He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a stranger! After Vitti leaves, Eddie enters from the other door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Eddie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch him like a hawk. If he steps out of line, it would break my heart, but shoot him in the fuckin' head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti is trying to sell an $80,000 Audi to the MacINERNYS, an upscale middle-aged couple. Vitti opens the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the size of that trunk. You could fit three people in there. (off their shocked looks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not people -- suitcases. It's a joke. The MacInernys laugh uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you driving now? MR. MacINERNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a Lexus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fancy Toyota, right? The Japs make good cars, but I ain't that quick to forget Pearl Harbor. The MacInernys look doubtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of well-heeled New Yorkers surround Vitti at the captain's station. Vitti, the new host, greets a prominen sports figure who embraces him like an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (signals the MAITRE D')

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mario, put Mr. Torre at table five. JOEY BOOTS, an old acquaintance of Vitti's, enters with a couple of his cronies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, I heard you were out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All dressed up for dinner, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The Maitre D' crosses away and waves at Vitti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, that table for six is ready. You can send them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're working here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah -- not really. It's like -- I'm on parole, so I just -- I come in, I greet people. Joey and his friends nod condescendingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I get it. Nice seein' you, Paul. Don't want to hold you up. You got people to seat. Joey and his guys walk away, they turn back and glance at Vitti, then whisper something in audible to each other and laugh. Vitti burns, humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH PHOTO
dialogues.text: Vitti poses for a picture with some notables.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PHOTO
dialogues.text: Vitti with some Broadway actors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti poses grimly with a BUSINESSMAN and his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Paul.    Appreciate it. Vitti moves to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, could you get us a big bottle of Pellegrino and another round of drinks? He slips Vitti a couple of bills.        Vitti stares at in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And more bread when you get a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want more bread? He takes a small loaf from the breadbasket on the next ta stuffs it into the Businessman's mouth and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get your drinks now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Hassidim are in the back of a 47th Street jewelry sto sorting through a huge pile of diamonds. Behind the    display counter, Vitti stares at the diamon breathing    hard, starting to perspire. His customers, a thirty-ish    YOUNG MAN and his FIANCEE, study the diamon engagement    ring on her finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stone is supposed to be a 'G' color, but it looks kind of yellow, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fluorescent light. Makes everything look yellow. He starts instinctively casing the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought fluorescent light makes everything look blue?

dialogues.speaker: FANTASY
dialogues.text: bound and gagged. END FANTASY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I -- Edison?    I'm telling you, it's a 'G.' He glances at the surveillance cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I look at it with a lens?

dialogues.speaker: FANTASY
dialogues.text: the camera lens and clipping the alarm wires. END FANTASY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lens.    Do you have a lens?

dialogues.speaker: FANTASY
dialogues.text: in the back as it BLOWS UP. END FANTASY.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Ben's cousin, approaches Vitti who is now hyperventilating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna do us both a big favor.    I quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MacInernys are trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see the manager? (grabs his crotch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the manager. Now take a hike, you fuckin' deadbeats. The MacInernys rush out of the showroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls after them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a Hyundai!

dialogues.speaker: DREAM SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Vitti is on the sofa. He's wearing a shiny, silk, short- sleeved shirt with the sleeves turned up, tight, black ch pants and short, black, pointy-toed boots. His hair is oi and coifed like early Frankie Avalon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distraught)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't deal with this shit. My grades suck, I'm gettin' in fights every day, and if I get suspended again my mother's gonna fuckin' kill me -- if the nuns don't kill me first.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: is listening to Vitti, but dressed as Sigmund Freud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eins, zwei, drei!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? VITTI'S MOTHER is sitting next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (elbows him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit up straight! Pay attention when the doctor talks to you. This is costing money. Ben (Freud) has a large TAXI METER TICKING away beside hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma?   What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorts some cocaine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acht gemacht gehunden nicht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell him the same thing. Suddenly, the WINDOWS are SHATTERED by GUNFIRE.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: BLASTS open, flying off the hinges. Jelly enters, pushed into the room by a gang of thugs, led by Patty LoPresti, Eddie DeVol and his guys, all at least ten-feet-tall and holding huge guns.

dialogues.speaker: VITTI
dialogues.text: leaps to his feet and reaches for his gun, but instead pu out a long sword. Confused but desperate, he holds up the sword to menace the intruders, but the sword suddenly goe limp. He tries to make the blade stand up, but it just ke dropping like a piece of soft rope. Patty, Eddie, and the thugs laugh contemptuously at Vitti while Jelly looks on with an incredible stream of tears pouring from his eyes. END DREAM SEQUENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vitti is back in bed in his robe, still asleep. The door opens and Laura enters with an interior decorator who has fabric samples over her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in here, I thought we'd get rid of the wallpaper and maybe put in some wainscoting -- She sees Vitti and quickly steers the decorator back outs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to decorator) Don't look, don't look. She comes back in, closes the bedroom door and confronts Vitti who is still groggy from his troubling dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize it's almost noon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Do me a favor, honey -- make me a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a sandwich? Make it yourself. I'm not afraid of you, Mr. Oh-I'm-A-Great-Big-Mobster Man. I want you out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had   it with the bathrobe and the skulking   around and the girlfriend who, I'm   sorry, is so obviously faking it's not   even funny. Enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda had that sandwich made by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries new tack) Okay. You don't like me and I don't like you. We can at least agree on that, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be honest with you -- I'm a very anxious person --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!    Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have so much in common. Anyway, this is not helping me, it's not helping my marriage, and I know Ben really needs some alone time. So I'm asking you -- as a human being -- could you please leave? (off Vitti's look) Yes, I'll make you a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ham, cheese, lettuce, tomato, mayonnaise, no onion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jelly   comes out the front door with Vitti's suitcases a pulls   into the driveway. He gets out of the car holding small   bag from the drugstore and sees Vitti coming out front   door. Ben stops him on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I going? The orphanage found my real parents. They want me back. (to Jelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put those in the car. (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' to Jelly's. Jelly carries the luggage to his car parked in the drivew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vitti)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you are. You're supposed to be in my custody. We have therapy today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? The more we talk the worse I get. I had that dream again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one where you're Mussolini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the other one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limp sword dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I probably shouldn't be listening to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
